review_content: Superbly acted, and following the Kazan-inspired happy ending third act written as a rather reluctant postscript, rather than the original original, it is a photographed stage play and we remain outside, in the audience.
movie_title: Cat on a Hot Tin Roof

review_content: Although the scope is small and the personas largely disagreeable, the performances are outstanding.
movie_title: Cat on a Hot Tin Roof

review_content: Tennessee Williams's overheated tale of familial strife in the Deep South comes alive in this atmospheric dramatisation - it's all steamy, fly-blown and shutters slammin'.
movie_title: Cat on a Hot Tin Roof

review_content: Brilliantly perceptive soap opera film noir.
Remarkable, unusual drama.
European incantation has given way to the shadows of American noir
... belongs as much to the murky world of American film noir as to the polished European dramas of high society social appearances and power games.
Despite the hurried wrapup Caught is mesmerizing in its orchestration of nuances.
Amidst Ophüls' precise, at times deliberately oppressive mise-en-scène, these three characters play out the contradictions of the American dream itself.
The contrasting black and white cinematography perfectly fits the dark mood. The fight sequences are excitingly and realistically staged.
Brilliant, searing, heartbreaking.
Douglas is so perfect in the role that the movie is never less than gripping.
Robson's direction is all action, wasting no time in telling this compelling story, and Carl Foreman's script is sharply observant of the boxing milieu.
One of the best fight films ever, also one of Kirk's best
In his first Oscar nomination in Mark Robson's compelling melodrama, Kirk Douglas gives a ferociously realistic performance as a boxer determined to succeed at all costs.
Kirk Douglas does a good, aggressive job, with a slight inclination to over-eagerness at times, which might amuse an old fight fan.
The Set-Up, made the same year, is infinitely superior.
Frank Planer's photography has much drama as the script as it begins to tell the story right under the titles and continues compelling on its course through the grim, relentless narrative.
A tight, gripping drama worth more to the movie customer than many multi-million epics.
There are only a couple of action scenes and they're okay, but the real joy is definitely from watching Hepburn and Grant together.
The many memorable twists and turns in the plot, and bizarre and violent situations include a classic, suspenseful and scary fight scene.
Charade reminds us that when all the elements come together, it's possible for Hollywood to make a flawless entertainment that thoroughly whisks us away. Too bad it doesn't happen more often.
Made when the studio system was on its last legs, Charade still feels fresh, quick-witted, nothing like the artificial, airless Hollywood pictures of its time.
An excellent piece of classic Hollywood entertainment.
Capable as a vaguely comic mystery.
Classy mystery that combines romance and comedy with a surprisingly suspenseful finish.
Everything about it is a little bit cleverer and a little bit better than it has to be. Thanks must be paid to both Donen and screenwriter Peter Stone.
The sexual chemistry between Hepburn and Grant, when set against Charade's tumultuous backdrop of shifting identities, makes this movie an enduring favorite.

Often described as the best Hitchcock movie Hitchcock never made, Charade stars Cary Grant and Audrey Hepburn in a sparkling thriller with overtones of screwball romantic comedy  or is it the other way around?
Sparkles with all the vigor of freshly uncorked champagne.
Charade is part thriller, part comedy and part old-fashioned romance, and classic-movie lovers will find it irresistable.
An appealing hybrid of romantic comedy and spy thriller. It's one of the best Hitchcock films that Hitchcock had nothing to do with.
The star power of Cary and Audrey is electrifying in this great comic thriller
I tell you, this light-hearted picture is full of such gruesome violence.
Stanley Donen's stylishly elegant, largely entertaining romance-thriller teams Cary Grant and Audrey Hepburn (then at the height of their careers) for the first and only time.
Donen's typically slick comedy thriller, ingeniously scripted by Peter Stone, is a mammoth audience teaser.
Smooth Donen thriller showcasing Cary and Audrey.
A smart Hitchcockian thriller.
even though the age difference is kinda weird the romance works
Firsttime teaming of Cary Grant and Audrey Hepburn, a natural, gives the sophisticated romantic caper an international appeal, + the selling points of adventure, suspense and suberb comedy.
It's glossy, charming, silly, and far too self-aware to be at all thrilling.
[An] enjoyably flashy Hitchcockian comedy thriller.
Charming comedy-romance-thriller pairing Cary Grant and Audrey Hepburn, intelligently scripted by Peter Stone and directed in distinctly Hitchcockian style by Stanley Donen.
What's going on is sort of confused.
A terrifically entertaining comedy-thriller.
If you haven't seen Charade, you really need to.
Cary Grant and Audrey Hepburn transcend several genres

A novel, auteur-driven film populated with reliably charismatic stars; even at the age of 50 it leaves most modern produce in the dust. It was also a hit. Five decades later, why has Hollywood not learnt their lesson?
Charade is able to successfully transcend the romance, comedy, and suspense thriller genres because of the cast, screenplay, and score.
...not a single thing is taken seriously in Charade.
The film has the laughter and excitement of Hitchcock, without the sadism.

Since the plot does not bear close tracking, let me note simply that Cary Grant still looks imperishable, Audrey Hepburn still looks like a Givenchy foundling, and the entire affair is carried off as a mild joke upon itself.
Charade allows itself to get slightly tangled up in its own plot.

It integrates comedy with a deep, dark mystery and winds up with a wild chase through the Paris subway. Admittedly, there are some incongruities and illogical situations, but the chances are that the viewers will be having too good a time to notice them.

Few thrillers create as much sheer joy and happiness as Charade, in which Cary Grant spoofs his Alfred Hitchcock persona, Audrey Hepburn exudes her usual magnetic charm, and Paris is as scenic as ever.
Throw in some interesting corpses, some thrilling action scenes and piquant moments of romance and you have it. A thoroughly polished comedy.
This absolutely wonderful comedy thriller from Stanley Donen (co-director, with Gene Kelly, of On the Town and Singin' in the Rain) nearly out-Hitchcocks Hitchcock.
Directed with an arched eyebrow by Stanley Donen, the film was released just weeks after John F Kennedy's assassination, giving shellshocked Americans a welcome bite of Hollywood candyfloss.
Quick and quippy and fun
ripping little drama
Great stars, great director, muddled message melodrama.

Preceding Bonnie and Clyde by a year, Arthur Penn's small-town drama, flaunting a top-notch cast (Brando, Redford, Jane Fonda) is a quintessential movie pointing to the thematic and tonal direction Hollywood would take in the late 1960s.
A Texas-style Peyton Place that's possibly more absurd.
The assassinations of Kennedy and Oswald are allegorically present in Lilliam Hellman's magnificent script... This is a progressive and self-critical film. [Full Review in Spanish]

The "New Hollywood" of the 1960s and 70s produced a number of withering takes on American institutions, but no filmmaker was as consistently convinced of the venality at the heart of American society as Arthur Penn.
Hysterical, extravagant, preposterous... Yet through all the Wagnerian excesses of the film, one can't help remembering the real events of this summer in Texas.
Considering the sprawling cast of distinctive characters and personalities, The Chase remains a compact exercise in control.
Solid version of the story, but eclipsed by the 1951 film.
This is a timeless ode to Dikie- Look for the Barrymore version too...
Second best version of holiday must-see.
Edwin L. Marin robustly directs the Charles Dickens classic.
Most viewers will still remember other versions of the film more readily, but this is one worth seeking out 'round holiday time.
The movie is nothing if not sincere, which goes a long way in a sentimental tale like this one.
A great and eternally heart-warming film that can stand an appreciative viewing every year through every decade.
Although slightly corn-ball, this 1938 production...should appeal to fans of old-fashioned Hollywood-style filmmaking.
A gentle, less scary version of the classic.
Effective adaptation of Charles Dickens novel, well acted by Reginald Owen and the rest of the cast.
[A] typically polished MGM version of Charles Dickens's yuletide favourite.
All in all, though, this is all very fluffy and silly and perfectly wonderful.
Frolicsome in an artificially hearty sort of way.
Silly as its premise may be, the film itself is both hilarious and heart-warming.
A gem of a holiday comedy: Stanwyck is adorable
Okay, mildly amusing Christmas fare.
Breezy, fun holiday comedy that has dated somewhat.
Delightfully cheerful screwball comedy that is especially suited for the Christmas holidays.
reasonably good fun, and Stanwyck actually overcomes the role's limitations
Peter Godfrey, the director, has a good deal to learn about the art of telling a boudoir joke in the parlor and getting away with it.
A sometimes hilarious farce and a holiday favorite.

If this mildly amusing screwball comedy about mistaken identity has a conservative slant of glorifying housewives it's due to the zeitgeist: It was made in 1945, at the end of WWII, when men were coming home and women sent back to the kitchen.
Thoroughly moth-eaten.
Barbara Stanwyck uses every acting muscle in her body to redeem this silly holiday romance.

It's nothing that's going to change your life or anything but if you want a pleasant and romantic comedy that has some good laughs and some good chemistry it's a... really entertaining little Christmas movie.
Critically lauded at the time of its release, Cimarron was beloved by most who saw it. Eight decades later, it is frequently cited on lists of the most undeserving Academy Award winners.
For pure history, this is a must, but it's laughable at times because of its overwrought machismo and intense over-acting.
Maybe the most undeserving Best Picture winner ever.
An early talkie, it now looks very dated.
Taken by itself, as a film, without moral conundrums, it's actually a fairly engaging yarn. However -- and this is a HUGE however -- it's incredibly racist in its stereotyping of all sorts of people.
There's a reason Wesley Ruggles' movies aren't often revived and this is one of them.
Cimarron, a rather weak film, is one of the few Westerns to win the Best Picture Oscar.
Too bad the rest of the film doesn't measure up to the opening.
A graphic and engrossing screen conception.
Consistently dull, this old western tale is highlighted by an endearing debut performance by Irene Dunne.
It holds up surprisingly well today.
This is a spectacular western away from all others. It holds action, sentiment, sympathy, thrills and comedy -- and 100% clean.
The first western to win an Oscar for Best Picture.
It is a long, full-bodied picture, paced so deftly that although it covers more than half a century of crowded, changing events, it never drags and is rarely jerky.
Get past the occasionally dated feel of Cimarron and you'll find a cracking yarn, one that does eventually make up for itself.
I can see the epic tragic scope that Cimarron was going for, and I can glean the dramatic irony inherent in the hugeness of it all, but it just doesn't work. It's a stiff, unengaging movie.
"Cimarron" is magnificent in scope, powerful in treatment, admirable in acting. But it is even more than all this. It is one of few talking picture productions which inspires rather than awes.

As a motion picture, this is fairly worthless, crippled by static direction, overblown performances and dull conflicts. But as a study of the American mindset at the time of both the story's setting and the film's production, it's a fascinating look back.

It is impossible, of course, in a short notice to give any real idea of so full and detailed a picture -- but Cimarron is emphatically a film which everyone looking for a good entertainment should see.
Anyone who wants to see the best Western needs to admire Cimarron. [Full Review in Spanish]
The all-time worst winner of the Academy Award for Best Picture.
With due regards to the author's craftsmanship, the picture version seems better than the original.
The conclusion of the story... is not in the least convincing.
Despite Yancey's admirable causes, the pacing is slow and the narrative uninspired, resulting in an important yet ponderous extravaganza.
...not required viewing by any means, nor is it the bomb it is sometimes made out to be...
A moderately successful, generally entertaining, but overly ambitious movie.
It's asp-tastic.
amazing that 20th Century Fox survived this train wreck long enough to produce Star Wars some 14 years later
A giant white elephant of a movie, a bloated monument to hubris and excess.
A stunning achievement compared to its present day counterparts.
Cleopatra will go down in film history as the most opulent, pictorially magnificent and eye-filling screen spectacle ever made -- as well as the longest.
opulent and empty, it dares you not to take a nap
Better than I thought it would be.
The movie is also dotted with some battle sequences of nearly epic proportions, but they can't make up for Cleopatra's shortcomings in plot and acting.
Taylor, Burton, and Harrison are sublime in this sweeping epic of love and nations.
Power and passion are the twin and intertwined themes of Cleopatra, and they have never burned with greater intensity or amid such opulence as they do in this extraordinary film.
It is a surpassing entertainment, one of the great epic films of our day.
Harrison, doing his waspish don act as Caesar, alone rises above mediocrity.
Cleopatra is not only a supercolossal eye-filler (the unprecedented budget shows in the physical opulence throughout), but it is also a remarkably literate cinematic recreation of an historic epoch.
For four hours this moody, glossy pantomime leadenly plods on, saying much more about the hubris and excess of old-time Hollywood thinking than the burnished glories of an ancient world.
A giant of a movie that is sometimes lumbering, but ever watchable thanks to its uninhibited ambition, size and glamour.
[A] general muddle.
This is not a film -- it's a deal, decorated with extensive publicity, but weighed down by listless direction and lots of nasal talk, talk, talk.

Much maligned, this Cleopatra might be the most expensive movie made, but not the worst, just an overly verbose affair, effective as star vehicle for Elizabeth Taylor, who commands regally, and Burton, who delivers his lines with authority and pathos.

Sad to say, however, the deep-revolving, witty Mankiewicz fails most where most he hoped to succeed. As drama and as cinema, Cleopatra is raddled with flaws. It lacks style both in image and in action.
It's a once-in-a-lifetime experience, for good and ill.
A stately but sometimes mindboggling spectacle.
Melodramatic, and camp as Christmas, but nothing like the disaster its reputation suggests.
The film at least manages to make some sense of an extraordinary moment in history, as Rome expanded from republic to empire.

Though it owes as much to Shakespeare's interpretation and to Roman propaganda as to the historical record, this interpretation of the great queen's life succeeds in conveying something of the intelligence and force of personality her opponents feared.
A lumbering monstrosity of a movie with all manner of preposterous hairstyles and improbable fashions. Worth seeing -- once anyway -- at least as wayward legend.
The film has a spectacular variety of liabilities (and, to be fair, strengths as well), but the most visible and crushing is that's an utter dud as a star vehicle.
Taylor inhabits the role with a focussed but uninhibited imperiousness, as when she turns Cleopatra's entrance into Rome, aboard a giant rolling sphinx, into the ultimate red-carpet photo op.
Four-hour visual stunner requires patience, maturity.
...a tale of two men being manipulated, and possibly loved, by a powerful and conflicted woman.

It may not be as compelling and tightly edited as Ben-Hur, but Cleopatra is still a Hollywood epic that tells a grand story in a grand way. Save it for a night when the family feels like a four-hour spectacle.
To watch this film is to see the Hollywood story itself.

The spectacular scenes were confused and oddly -cule... Still and all, there was Elizabeth Taylor. At first I was disappointed, a large statement considering my expectations. Then I realized what she was up to and didn't regret my $1.25.
Rex Harrison is the undisputed hit of the show as a subtle and sardonic Julius Caesar...
Worth a look.... for a single performance: Rex Harrison as Caesar.
As the sets seem to grow bigger and bigger, so progressively the players dwindle.
Buster on the playing field, failing gloriously at every sport but executing each one beautifully when he dashes to his girl's rescue, is a study in precision and grace.
The finale ties earlier elements together in a clever way, but the episodic film doesn't match the best of Keaton's films that establish a more cohesive storyline
Great Keaton vehicle.
A classic comedy with Keaton in top acrobatic form.
it's not the General but it's a treasure
Madcap fun as the supremely athletic Keaton plays a bookworm who, for love of a jock-loving girl, tries but fails heroically at every possible sport in every possible way.
Keaton himself strives to be funny, but his actions are so frightfully absurd that it strikes one that the character he plays never ought to be out of an asylum.
Minor Keaton but major almost any other comedian.
Minor Keaton slapstick comedy.
A fine and funny film.
Cartesian slapstick
The movie is worth seeing for a lot of reasons, one of them being the weirdly elegant pratfall Keaton takes on the baseball diamond when he gets clipped by an opposing player sliding into third.
Keaton helped write the textbook on comedy, and in College he gives us a master class.
Running a brisk 65 minutes, College is sparse on story, heavy on gags. Keaton knew how to get straight to the good stuff.
Two of Hollywood's greatest stars give what might be their best performances.
If you enjoy Crosby as a crooner instead of a showman, this is your movie.
The backstage drama, when judged by today's standards, seems stagy, creaky and outdated.
Based on Odets' play, Seaton's version is an odd, overrated melodrama about co-dependency in alcoholic marriages, with decent turns by Bing Crosby and Grace Kelly as the central couple.
Great acting, heavy themes in Old Hollywood classic.
A lush 1944 musical vehicle built for Rita Hayworth at the height of her popularity.
The story is pretty vacuous and the ending obvious, but it is still pleasant enough viewing with a clutch of toe-tapping tunes courtesy of Gershwin and Kern.
Overlooked musical with some great numbers. C'mon, pearl!
Cover Girl is a mixed but colorful bag.
Great songs, great dancing - an almost-great musical.
It has Gene Kelly and Rita Hayworth to sing and dance. And virtually every nook and corner is draped with beautiful girls.
The whole thing, especially the comic stuff from Silvers and Arden, is executed with considerable brio. And Rudolph Mat's Technicolor photography is faultless.
Its familiar tale of an ambitious chorus girl's sudden rise to fame is pleasant enough but not fresh enough to hold my attention.
Dance sequences spotlighting the terping abilities of Hayworth and Kelly are expertly staged.
This Oscar-nominated, lavishly produced musical catapulted Gene Kelly and Rita Hayworth to major stardom.

A creaking plot is made bearable by gorgeous colour, the even more gorgeous Hayworth, some oddly unsentimental and unsettling flashbacks with her playing her character's turn-of-the-century grandmother.
Charming musical built on a skimpy plot but boasting a score by Jerome Kern and Ira Gershwin that includes some of their best work.
This is what we're here for, larger than life emotions played out with unparalleled skill and imagination.
First class fun. [Full review in Spanish]
A classic horror that warms the heart.
[A] B movie classic.
The technical material is so good, in fact, that if you might actually like the movie... if you can ignore everything else.
This is still a decent movie and a good example of the monster movie genre.
Cool creature!
Its solitary aim was to exploit the viewer's fear of the unknown.
One of the best of the 1950's creature features. (By a long shot.)
Tremendous chilling fun, whether in 3-D or no. And Julia Adams is still hot in that swimsuit.
Great monster suit. Not much of a movie
Incluindo um curioso subtexto ecolgico, o filme envelheceu bem: pode at no assustar como na poca de seu lanamento, mas continua interessante.
Creepy underwater horror flick. Ahead of its time.
As directed by Jack Arnold, the film suffers from silly stretches of dialogue and wooden acting, but the underwater footage is still beautiful, and Adams radiates a strong, sexy screen presence.
Very neat
The routine story is mightily improved by Arnold's sure sense of atmospheric locations and by the often sympathetic portrait of the monster.
This adventure has no depth.
Imbued with great atmosphere by director Jack Arnold, the film is genuinely frightening, but also elicits a certain amount of pathos for the creature.
The underwater sequences were excellently shot by Havens, and the make-up for the half man, half fish was a masterful creation by Bud Westmore and Jack Keven.

Jack Arnold has a flair for this sort of thing, and if there really is anything frightening about a man dressed up in a rubber suit with zippers where the gills ought to be, Arnold comes close to finding it.
Jack Arnold's direction has done a firstrate job developing chills and suspense, and James C. Havens rates a good credit for his direction of the underwater sequences.
The beats of the film are like overused sandpaper, too worn down and tattered to have more than a passing effect.
What distinguished Jack Arnold's pictures from mutant spinoffs/knockoffs is even more imperative to sci-fi today than it was in 1954: wonderment.
When I was a kid, this was the movie monster I wanted to be.
Okay, it's just a guy in a rubber suit. Even people in the 1950's weren't afraid of this so-called monster. But, there's some camp value to this on-the-water and under-the-water adventure.
It makes for solid horror-thrill entertainment.
The whole thing is ultimately just a '50s B-movie, but it's hard to imagine what they could have done to make it a better one.
This is a pulp classic with good reason.
This is certainly one of the most fondly remembered of the science fiction films of the 1950s.

Along comes one of those tedious, topeed expeditions, in a battered white boat, and the "Gill-Man" is chased, photographed, speared, half-asphyxiated, and screamed at. No wonder he commits murder (five of them).
The boys at Universal were on a fanciful binge, putting on an enjoyable show in the water, something less in dry-dock.
Short on science, the picture's long enough on excitement, strongly recalling the hit Beast from 20,000 Fathoms.
A prehistoric man shaped fish falls in love with screaming Julia Adams in an Amazon backwater, but his courtship is a failure. So is the movie.
There are some effective underwater scenes; otherwise script and direction are commonplace.
The subject matter has been handled in a way that makes for a maximum of suspense and with an eye toward satisfying those who seek horrific chills and thrills.
It's horribly dated, the acting's lousy, the 3D effects are worthless and the monster is a man in a rubber suit. Yet Creature from the Black Lagoon remains one of the all-time classic monster movies.
Why did and does Hollywood continue to put non-singers in musicals? No one in this movie has a good voice.
Miss Verdon has the sort of fine, fresh talent that the screen badly needs these days.
It might be one of the more implausible spins on the old legend, but it's certainly one of the most entertaining.
Hard to watch, TV-looking filmed stage play with some good songs and Ray Walston.
Not the equal of Stanley Donen's parallel project, The Pajama Game, but a fine and vigorous film of the Broadway musical nonetheless.
The movie's got a team-load of spunk and spirit that go a long way toward entertaining an audience.
hasn't aged very well
While watching Damn Yankees offers many pleasures, none compare to the spectacle of Tab Hunter in the prime of his beauty.
One of the better big-budget music-fests ... mainly because it has the devil and some baseball in it.
A musical lumbered with too much plot.
This version of the Broadway hit offers a rare opportunity to see most of the stage performers recreating their roles, + an early glimpse of the genius of Bob Fosse.
The Damn Yankees team, which ran the score high for three seasons in Broadway's legit ballpark, was reassembled to go to bat in this sparkling film version.
Terrific, Oscar-nominated score by Jerry Ross and Richard Adler is electric.
As a cinemusical, Yankees manages to steal home by a wide margin.
A lively celebration of baseball as America's pastime set during an era where the game was at its peak.

The problem lies with Tab Hunter in the difficult leading role: to put it mildly, he lacks pizzazz. There's still a lot of fun to be gleaned, though: Gwen Verdon is a knockout as Lola, and Ray Walston is arguably the definitive movie Devil, Mr Applegate.
Bette Davis won her first Oscar for playing an alcoholic actress bent on self-destruction.
Early Bette Davis is fun to catch.
Dreadful soap opera film.
Dangerous, then, is unusual, but only because of Miss Davis.
Dangerous gives Bette Davis an opportunity to exercise her special type of eerie fascination.
The actress part gives Bette Davis every opportunity to do her drunken haridan, and she does her to the hilt. An enjoyable, though crude stunt.
If not for Christie's brilliant performance, I would say that this isn't much above a movie of the week.
Julie Christie thoroughly merited her Oscar as the immoral but vivacious starlet hellbent on fame and Dirk Bogarde as her TV journalist lover is equally splendid.
Christie's Oscar-winning portrayal hasn't aged a bit, even if the movie's swinging '60s milieu has.
Darling is as empty of meaning and mind as the empty life it's exposing.

A transitional work between the British "Kitchen Sink" realism and the more stylized works of siwnging London, Schlesinger's film has not aged particularly well, but Julie Christie is beautiful and captivating as the immoral and amoral heroine.
Julie Christie is must-see in Oscar winning performance.
John Schlesinger's Darling is a film of excessive and self-defeating brilliance.
A rather constipated and badly dated Brit New Wave social satire film.
...a time-capsule curiosity that thoroughly squanders a fine performance from its talented star.
John Schlesinger has shot the film in a series of compelling slabs, significant instalments in a success story on which the heroine herself makes intermittent comments.
...it's a quality Darling catches perfectly. "The research period was enormously entertaining," he says, and so is the movie.
An interesting failure: all the parts work, but somehow they don't make a whole.
I hope that Darling, Schlesinger, will finally establish him where he belongs -- in the very first rank of the younger directors.
Excruciatingly embarrassing at the time, it now looks grotesquely pretentious and pathetically out of touch with the realities of the life-styles that it purports to represent.
[Schlesinger] has made a film that will set tongues to wagging and moralists to wringing their hands.
Miss Christie's performance is remarkably vibrant and outgoing.
Gort! Klaatu barada nikto.

review_content: From beginning to end, The Day the Earth Stood Still is a lot of fun.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still

review_content: Next time your parents tell you that they don't make them like they used to, believe them.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still

review_content: It is one of the first films of the period to question the cold war even if on an allegorical basis.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still

review_content: One of the top, let's say, two science fiction films ever made.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still

review_content: Classic sci-fi film that still has some power
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still

review_content: A sci-fi classic
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still

review_content: It is a handsome, thoughtful fable with a thriller element and a slightly evasive ending.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still

review_content: A true 1950s drive-in classic.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still

review_content: The title alone inspires awe.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still

review_content: Long considered a touchstone in science fiction cinema, this stood apart from most of the other 50s sci-fi outings for many reasons.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still

review_content: The film is very good at showing how effortlessly misunderstandings can develop between ordinary people and between nations and how easily fear can overwhelm reason and understanding.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still

review_content: This is no ordinary sci-fi flick.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still

review_content: It is comforting, of course, to have it made plain that our planetary neighbors are much wiser and more peaceful than are we, but this makes for a tepid entertainment in what is anamolously labeled the science-fiction field.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still

review_content: Today, wistful viewers might ask: Where are Klaatu and Gort when we need them most?
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still

review_content: The most amazing thing about this excellent film is how well it has held up and how its message is just as true today as it was in the immediate post-Second World War years.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still

review_content: This beloved science-fiction film shows what happens to the alien Klaatu and his robot Gort after they land their spaceship on Earth.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still

review_content: I always have to change the channel when this is on for some reason
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still

review_content: One of the best from the Cold War School of space movies.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still

review_content: A first-rate science fiction classic.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still

review_content: "Klaatu Barada Nikto" are the words that launched a thousand spaceships in this early sci-fi standard.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still

review_content: Absolutely among the top 5 sci-fi films ever. Keep going, Gort!
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still

review_content: Though made half a century ago, this film remains a seminal sci-fi and a defining moment in the genre's history as well as in the visual treatment of fear of atomic bomb.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still

review_content: still fantastic
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still

review_content: Very good, but slowish and slightly high-minded.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still

review_content: Edmund H North's intelligent script and Wise's smooth direction are serious without being solemn, while Bernard Herrmann's effectively alien-sounding score reinforces the atmosphere of strangeness and potential menace.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still

review_content: This is a superbly crafted, landmark film which invested a much-derided -- and frequently ludicrous -- genre with a welcome degree of dignity and respectability.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still

review_content: The naivete of some of the film's thinking is trumped by the virtue that it's thinking at all, and that it asks us to do likewise.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still

review_content: Like most of Robert Wise's work, this slickly constructed 1951 science fiction film settles squarely in the middle of its genre, better than some and worse than others.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still

review_content: Superb performances by all involved, restrained direction by Wise, and a magnificent and innovative score by Bernard Herrmann help keep this 35-year-old film just as relevant today as it was the day it was released.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still

review_content: Cast, although secondary to the story, works well.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still

review_content: The Day the Earth Stood Still may at first look like goofy, outdated science fiction, but its timeless warnings about violence, nuclear confrontation and the difficulties of policing the planet have made it an enduring cultural classic.

review_content: ...dispels any notion you might have about shlocky science fiction.

review_content: Iconic from the get-go.

review_content: More thoughtful and restrained than most sci-fi of the period, The Day the Earth Stood Still has aged better than almost all of its peers.

review_content: Made at the time as a plead for international peace, its message should still ring true today where the world picture is more complex and, in many ways, more splintered and dangerous.

review_content: The Day the Earth Stood Still (1951) is one of the most influential, seminal fantasy science fiction films in motion picture history. The counter-revolutionary, big-budget film provided salient social commentary about the madness of Cold War politics...

review_content: Days of Wine and Roses (1962) is the intense dramatic portrayal of an alcoholic, co-dependent couple. The film's poster describes its intriguing premise: "It is Different. It is Daring. Most of All, in Its Own Terrifying Way, It is a Love Story."
Hollywood doesn't make 'em like this anymore.

Except for the (fake) ending, this is one of Hollywood's best films about the devastating effects of alcoholism, going beyond Wilder's Lost Weekend, and proficiently helmed by Blake Edwards just before the Pink Panther films changed completely his career
Grim, strong drama about alcoholism with Lemmon and Remick's stellar work.
Days is a tract, my friend, a folded brochure of a film, rescued by Jack Lemmon's charm and some good dark camerawork.
Jack Lemmon, hitherto chiefly identified with comedy roles, establishes himself as an actor of impressive range in this tough-minded Hollywood drama about alcoholism.
Lemmon has given a sizable number of terrific performances over his career, and this one qualifies as a Top 10 entry. As for Remick, she's never been better.
The movie plays like an extended ad for Prohibition, three decades after it ended.
Pretty good hardboiled thriller with Lizabeth Scott an OK stand-in for Bacall.
A bleak crime melodrama that is too complexly plotted for it own good.
[A] deficient noir.
Solid version of the play with strong cast.
An aged fiftysomething Humphrey Bogart is in his element as the snarling desperate fugitive, a role played on Broadway by the much younger Paul Newman.
William Wyler's taut direction elevates this thriller, which stars Bogart in his last screen role and Fredric March; far superior to the 1991 remake.

William Wyler's masterly filming of the Joseph Hayes thriller makes most of the earlier versions look like minor-league efforts. Fredric March, as the beleaguered father, gives one of the year's finest acting performances.
A fun, off-beat little horror film

Although deliberately created to replicate the dummy episode from DEAD OF NIGHT, this black-and-white English production works tolerably well as a crude rip-off, thanks to a creepy dummy and creepier performance from Haliday as The Great Vorelli.
A masterfully-directed comedy, Dinner at Eight (1933), filled with a tremendous cast of stars all invited
the kind of smart, upscale adult comedy-drama that would never get made these days
Feels like a very good, very entertaining movie, but Grand Hotel feels like something truly special. However, the good in Dinner at Eight is very good indeed.
Each star has a memorable moment.
The dinner party that closes Dinner at Eight wouldn't feel like dancing at the end of the world without Renault's final gesture.
A sparkling script and game efforts from an all-star cast easily overcome the creakiness.
Scintillating '30s comedy with an all-star cast and quip-happy script.
Taking advantage of MGM's talent pool, George Cukor directed this witty 1933 comedy with a big-gun cast that includes Marie Dressler, John Barrymore, Wallace Beery, and Jean Harlow.
Features a stellar cast of all-star MGM veterans who all know how to overact.
A deluxe flipbook of caricatures, a blatant pageant of studio thoroughbreds, a study of tuxedoed, bejeweled pretense
It's a little rough around the edges, but the performances from these legendary actors really make this movie worthy of your time
Put Dinner at Eight down as an exceptionally fine directorial job and place Cukor higher on your list of directors as a result of it.

In it are Marie Dressier, Lionel and John Barrymore, Wallace Beery, Lee Tracy, Edmund Lowe, Madge Evans. Karen Morley, Billie Burke, Phillips Holmes and Jean Harlow. You take all the others and leave us Jean Harlow.
Audiences of the era may have been fascinated to see the inner workings of the upper crust, but these are painfully dull, generic ordeals.
The movie is something that should be experienced by everyone at least once in a lifetime.
Plays as a sweeping, episodic tale set against the backdrop of World War I and the Russian Revolution, with some of the most stunning vistas ever captured on film.
Lean discovered, and fell in love with, Julie Christie, and knew straightaway that his audience would too.
When the bland epics of Sir Richard Attenborough and Roland Joffe are long forgotten, people will still be watching David Lean's work.
Although its portentous historical drama evaporates once you return to the fresh air, watching it can be seductive.
Lean's last great film.
Often the dialogue is nearly as rich as the costumes and settings.
Lean's mastery of the epic form makes up for a weak central love story
Long, but lovely and romantic, and epic!
Mr. Bolt has reduced the vast upheaval of the Russian Revolution to the banalities of a doomed romance.
Fails to excite the imagination.
David Lean masterpiece has great performances, sets
Steiger and Courtenay excepted, all the performances are very uncomfortable.
Beautiful cinematography...and set design...together with excellent performances combine to form Zhivago's timeless appeal

David Lean's 1965 adaptation of Pasternak's romance of the Russian Revolution is intelligent and handsomely mounted, though it doesn't use its length to build to a particularly complex emotional effect.
As always, Lean's handling of the purely physical aspects of the material is spectacular.
One of the most meticulously designed and executed films.

Combining skill and kitsch in equal measure, David Lean's overbloated epic (a disappointing follow-up to Lawrence of Arabia) offers guilty pleasure so long as you don't expect a faithful adaptation of Joe Pasternak's novel about the Russian Revolution.
Laborious, but beautifully crafted 193 minute opus from the master of epic cinema, David Lean.
Literate, oldfashioned, soul-filling and thoroughly romantic.
[Lean] seems out of his element.
...a passionate movie about passionate people in passionate times.
A triumph of great entertainment. Whether it is great filmmaking is a matter of taste.
it is to be respected for the massive success and artistry of the decade in which it was made
Epic drama combines romance, politics, mature themes.
...an apocalypse movie in the guise of a romantic period piece.

Whatever its flaws, films made with this much chutzpah last forever. Doctor Zhivago wears its daunting runtime like the lightest of shawls and, even after all these years, it's still worth surrendering your heart to.
Yes it's old-fashioned and sappy. But it's impossible not to swoon.
Lean and Bolt pay tribute to a Tolstoyan ambition in Pasternak's samizdat novel, and also to a real contemporary relevance: the story of a suppressed writer.
Demands everything from the viewer while offering little in return, with Lean coming across like a despised schoolmaster not wanting to open himself up to his braying students.
This adaptation of Boris Pasternak's classic novel has all the sweep and stateliness that characterised David Lean's mastery of the epic.
Maurice Jarre's music is as beguiling as ever and Lean squeezes all the pathos that he can out of the romance between Sharif's Yuri Zhivago and Julie Christie's febrile and gorgeous Lara Antipova.
The best one can say of Doctor Zhivago is that it is an honest failure.
Epic seems too small a word for the sweeping ambition and romance of Doctor Zhivago.
One of those rare film adaptations which, unless you have already read the book, makes you wonder why anyone ever bothered to make the film at all.
Despite the grim and brooding background, Zhivago has a surging buoyant spirit that is unquenchable. Doctor Zhivago is more than a masterful motion picture; it is a life experience.
David Lean has made a stunning motion picture from Boris Pasternak's Nobel Prize novel.
...still the best epic around...
A true Saturday afternoon extravaganza.
[Doctor Zhivago] is, in its skill and finish, everything a "big" picture should be and rarely is.
A masterpiece of emotional resonance and melodramatic romanticism.
Lavish super western still works.
Anything that could be brought to a Western was done so in "Dodge City".
A well-crafted and perfectly capable western.
A sprawling epic Western influenced by the Wyatt Earp legend.
Conventional western gets lavish Warners treatment
Much fun.
Top line Warners western w/heroic Errol Flynn's guns blazin'!

Dodge City spirited Errol Flynn away from his swashbuckling milieu and into a Wild West setting, and the match proved so natural that the Australian actor found himself cast in several more sagebrush sagas over the ensuing years.
Rousing, entertaining Western, with an anti-dictatorship, pro-democracy theme.
''Dodge City,'' Michael Curtiz's rousing 1939 oater about the civilizing of the ''wide-open Babylon of the American West,'' has everything...
A big splashy Hollywood spectacle, with gorgeous sets and a riot of colors in the costumes and wide-open skies.
In the middle of a frantic Christmas season, there is no better respite from the buy-me commercialism of the holidays than this short, but poignant story by Dr. Seuss.
Christmas isn't Christmas without the Grinch.
Like fine wine, it just gets better every darn year.
I love Rankin-Bass, sure, but give me this any and every Christmas.
A seasonal classic.
It's the kind of weirdly clever, yet innocent and kid-friendly, product that forces me to use this tired clich -- they just don't make 'em like this any more
Forget director Ron Howard's ill-conceived, live-action version of How the Grinch Stole Christmas. The only cinematic take the story needed was released as an animated television special in 1966.
Chuck Jones's wonderful 1966 television special remains a model of economy, taking Dr. Suess's simple tale and perfectly stretching it out to 26 minutes.
Classic Christmas animated tale, a perennial on TV.
I've always thought Boris Karloff's last great role was as the snarling, malevolent voice of the Grinch in this 1966 television cartoon.
This lusty, garishly colored, good-hearted cartoon was a wonderful, awful idea.
Heartwarming TV special true to Seuss' classic.
It's such a wonderful combination of talents and rich enthusiasm for the source material, that it's tough to not like it.
Its brightness, cleanness, tightness, and wit all go in to making it feel as fresh and alive as any other piece of animation from its generation.

The special works because of its surprisingly sentimental climax, one that comes by its emotion honestly, as the Grinch realizes the Christmas spirit is indomitable, no matter what he does to stop it.
The story might be familiar, but watching The Grinch tiptoe around to "You're a Mean One, Mr. Grinch" always brings a surge of fuzzy nostalgia every Christmas season that never seems to get old.
Dracula deserves its status as a classic, although one might be tempted to append the word 'lesser' to that label.
Bela Lugosi is inspired in the role of the vampire. One can no longer label it a good performance or a bad performance. Lugosi embodies the role.
Dracula (1931) is one of the earliest classic American horror films from Universal Pictures - an acclaimed masterpiece directed by Tod Browning
Creepily beautiful.
Certainly it is Lugosi's performance, and the cinematography of Karl Freund, that make Tod Browning's film such an influential Hollywood picture.
While Lugosi is of course memorable, don't forget Helen Chandler's Mina, who communicates more through her eyes than virtually any other actress caught on film.
...a motion picture for people who love motion pictures, their history, and their evolution. It is a self-recommending classic.
uma pena que o vampiro absoluto das telas, Bela Lugosi, no tenha estrelado um filme perene como a lenda em que ele se tornou.
Still the best American take on the infamous bloodsucker.
Campy by today's standards, but still the melancholic master of fright flicks.
When Bela Lugosi died he was buried wearing one of his original silk capes. Forever cloaked, he casts his shadow still.
...the film survives as a classic horror tale largely because of Lugosi's distinctive portrayal as Dracula.
Despite its reputation as a horror classic, Dracula is tedious, stagebound and dull; saved only by Lugosi's perfomance.
With Mr. Browning's imaginative direction and Mr. Lugosi's makeup and weird gestures, this picture succeeds to some extent in its grand guignol intentions.
Bathed in an atmosphere of nightmare, dread and otherworldliness that is unlike anything else in American horror cinema.
Dracula takes place within the confines of the parlors and drawing rooms of London society, which bears a striking resemblance to Americana circa 1931.
After Lugosi, all vampire performances are doomed to be compared against him as either homage or departure.
It haunted no one as much as dear Bela...
[The music] contributes to Tod Browning's marvellous tone of restrained horror and stylish after-life.
there is a reason why Bela ended up in Ed Wood movies
Once you get into the rhythms of the film, you'll discover a masterpiece.
Not by any means the masterpiece of fond memory or reputation, although the first twenty minutes are astonishingly fluid and brilliantly shot by Karl Freund.
Bela Lugosi gives the performance of his life in a role that might have been written just for him. Highly atmospheric throughout, this remains a milestone in horror movie history.

The atmospheric opening is the best part -- moody and full of sinister potential. After that, it's stilted drawing-room talk, variably acted, except for the cultish over-the-top dementia of Dwight Frye.
The opening scenes, set in Dracula's castle, are magnificent -- grave, stately, and severe. But the film becomes unbearably static once the action moves to England.
All time horror classic starring Lugosi; still creepy as blazes.
A sublimated ghost story related with all surface seriousness and above all with a remarkably effective background of creepy atmosphere.
An exciting melodrama, not as good as it ought to be but a cut above the ordinary trapdoor-and-winding-sheet type of mystery film.
A classic despite numerous flaws.

Stark, cold, and deeply sensual, "Dracula's" atmosphere and intention is rooted in a fear of unknown lust and desire from which there can be no escape. To view "Dracula" is to be bitten by the vampire's desperate attack.
A perfect example of the worst traits of Hollywood films in the early sound era.
Lugosi's seminal performance and the striking opening act are what distinguish Browning's version of the classic tale.
...it's clear that the movie simply doesn't hold up terribly well all these years later.
It remains the most subtly romantic and highly atmospheric rendition of Bram Stoker's tale about the Transylvanian count, with Browning orchestrating the opening scenes to macabre perfection.
It's a case of lightning-in-a-bottle casting and there's no way of telling if anyone else as Dracula would've become the model for every single Dracula that followed.
Bela Lugosi gives his greatest performance as the mesmerizing menace from Transylvania. Dracula chilled audiences in the 1930's, and it still gives me goosebumps.

The abundance of older features on Blu-rays and DVDs have helped give younger filmgoers an appreciation of classic movies. "They can learn so much more on how to pace and set a scene from Tod Browning over Michael Bay," Mankiweicz said.
It's more fantasy than horror, though it excels in crafting a forbidding atmosphere.
A fantastic affirmation of genre made over a century ago. The beginning of something grandious. [Full article in Spanish].
James Dean is still the main reason why should we enjoy this very good example of 1950s cinema.
East of Eden (1955) is an updated telling of the Biblical story of rival brothers, Cain and Abel and a paradise lost.
In short, there is energy and intensity but little clarity and emotion in this film. It is like a great, green iceberg: mammoth and imposing but very cold.
Overwrought, often splendid Kazan version of the Steinbeck novel. The movie's chief distinction is the amazing debut of rebellious, romantic James Dean.
as exciting a drama as you're ever likely to see, and ultimately it's the unforgettable Dean that makes it so
A showcase for Dean's searing, gargantuan, force-of-nature performance.
If you turn the sound down on East of Eden (and, by all means, do), you'll see why Dean is a legend.
Dean's performance continues to resonant, still evoking today the same anger, anguish, and confusion of growing up that it did half a century ago.
A classic of its time.
the real reason that this film has any legs at all (and the ONLY reason that Warner Brothers has released the DVD) rests with James Dean
... can be seen as one of the earliest examples of the enshrinement of the unregenerate, semi-nihilistic "attitude" that informed and in part created "rock 'n' roll."
Kazan's Biblical allegory has not held up well, but Dean's performance, for which he was Oscar-nominated posthumously, proves why he became a star after his very first film
Not only one of Kazan's richest films and Dean's first significant role, it is also arguably the actor's best performance.
What could be a better way to spend two hours?
It's a film of great performances, atmospheric photography, and a sure sense of period and place.
James Dean's finest performance

John Steinbeck's painful biblical allegory -- Genesis replayed in Monterey, California, circa 1917 -- is more palatable on the screen, thanks to the down-to-earth performances of James Dean as Cal/Cain and Richard Davalos as Aron/Abel.
Kazan had the bad sense to leave out the best parts from the lengthy book.
Fine James Dean vehicle, one of few that put him into immortality.
East of Eden is set in 1917 but [James] Dean feels completely modern and contemporary, a boy not quite comfortable in his body.
a reaction to our plutocracy's values and a further case for Dean as the sainted figure of rebellion that would fuel the generational schism of the '60s.
After testing various performers (including a newcomer named Paul Newman), Kazan went with the unknown Dean, a move that immediately yielded dividends.
Catches fire in the clashes between Dean (as the bad brother) and Raymond Massey as his stiff-necked dad.
Rich historical detail and good visuals make interesting film.
It's far from a dull movie, but it's certainly a very strange one; it's an enshrinement of the mixed-up kid.
East of Eden deals with inner conflict; the entire story could be played out in a living room. Instead it sprawls all over the eye-filling landscape and the real action is padded ...
James Dean is decidedly the highlight of the film. His Method acting techniques and uninhibited performing style cause him to stand out among the more conventional cast.
Book-based classic has violence, drinking, mature themes.
The film ends on a flagrant miscalculation which typifies Kazan at his worst.
Frequently smart, engaging, emotional, and intermittently historical (presenting various attitudes toward international conflicts, patriotism, profits, and foreigners).
A fast moving film.

A histria bem construda e as boas atuaes so o ponto forte deste noir, que se inspirou em fatos reais e foi um dos primeiros filmes a abordar o universo dos assassinos profissionais - e Bogart, mesmo no piloto automtico,  sempre interessante.

Intelligence applied exactly where it is most rare: in the lavish, star-studded epic.
Propaganda masquerading as drama, it makes for a decidedly turgid viewing experience.
In the end, one should take from this picture a shaken feeling of having been through a lot of harsh and ennobling experiences.
Watchable mainly for the sheer skill and drive of Preminger's direction, although at 220 minutes even that long outstays its welcome.
A stirring chronicle of Israel's struggle for independence in 1947.
Otto - let my people go!
Preminger's ambitious chronicle of the formation of the State of Israel contains some stirring moments, but as an epic it's too sprawling, overlong, and lacks dramatic center.

Appallingly boring. That's a subjective word, but I can't think of a better one.

In 1960, Dalton Trumbo served up two hefty screenplays full of incident, emotion and intellectual exchanges -- I prefer Spartacus, although there's something to be said for his streamlining of so much historical content (and, yes, fictional deviations).
Most of the time seems well spent, although Dalton Trumbo's otherwise skilful screenplay includes too many garrulous slowdowns while the characters discuss their conflicting ideologies.
Exodus, then, sees Preminger's sheer movie-making talent at its most extended. Unhappily, the ability to sustain a large canvas does not necessarily result in a good film.
Weird, yes. And wonderful.
It's a totally intelligent film with a great message, wonderfully presented by Truffaut, with the upmost competence.
Fahrenheit 451 is made of scenes that are truly horrifying, some scenes that are filled with black humour and some scenes that are both.
... conveys Bradbury's intellectual vision well enough to stand the test of time more effectively than a number of mindless science fiction films

Francois Truffault's film adaptation of the classic Ray Bradbury novel is an interesting miss.
Intellectually engaging, dramatically kind of dull.
The movie is filmed in a rather low-key, dispassionate manner.
What's actually indicted is the human inclination towards the easy.
Holy smoke! What a pretentious and pedantic production he has made.
...celebrates the romance of the written word while also reveling in the medium that has replaced reading for many people, the cinema...

Fahrenheit 451 is a story about some future society in which it is a crime.to own books and book-burning is the chief job of firemen. As an idea it offers much but in execution makes only partial delivery.
This is the kind of film that should encourage the perceptive viewer to rush out to the library to read someone like Herman Melville before it's too late.
Dated and a little silly now, but one must love Ray Francois and Julie in a common mix.
A keen adaptation of Ray Bradbury's novel by Truffaut; eerie in its simplicity and matter-of-factness about book burning and Big Brotherism.
trgico constatar que a viso de Bradbury vem tornando-se cada vez mais real: a diferena  que, em vez de queimados, os livros vm sendo simplesmente ignorados.
While not one of Truffaut's strongest film, it is nonetheless one of his few explicitly political works and also boasts sharp imagery by Roeg) and indelible score by Herrmann.
An underrated film, perhaps because it is less science fiction than a tale of 'once upon a time.'
This 1966 film often looks good (it was Truffaut's first in color, photographed by Nicolas Roeg), but the ideas, such as they are, get lost in the meandering narrative.
A marvelously courageous personal statement that becomes more fascinating with time.

With a serious and even terrifying theme, this excursion into science fiction has been thoughtfully directed by Francois Truffaut and there is adequate evidence of light touches to bring welcome and needed relief to a sombre and scarifying subject.
On the downside, it doesn't particularly feel like a Truffaut film, but on the upside, it's a decent entry in the sci-fi genre.
Truffaut faces Bradbury's abstractions head on, not as science-fiction but as humanistic fairy-tale
Bradbury's 1954 vision of a totalitarian society where technology is worshiped and books are burned has been neutered and consigned to camp.
Even at the science-fiction horror-story level, the movie fails -- partly, I think, because Truffaut is too much of an artist to exploit the vulgar possibilities in the material.
Truffaut's movie clearly suffered from a troubled shoot - Truffaut didn't actually know English - so his oddball take on the material succeeds in only fits and bursts.
It is as though Truffaut has drawn on everything he knows about cinema to express unshakable loyalty to the written word.
Truffaut brought more cinematic acumen to this minute-long sequence than many filmmakers deploy in an entire feature.
Ultimately, the film has a powerful emotional impact, but it is achieved the hard way -- through the mind rather than the viscera -- and only in Its own good time.
Mitchum makes a perfect Marlowe.
Truly fine neo-noir compares favorably with the 1944 version.
A romantic detective story starring Robert Mitchum that harkens back to a time when even gumshoes had their own moral code
Terrific casting, terrific noir thriller.
Farewell, My Lovely is a great entertainment and a celebration of Robert Mitchum's absolute originality.
The film's success lies in Mitchum's hard-boiled portrayal of Marlowe.
It's as if someone had put pillow springs, power-steering and a tape deck into a classic racing-car. It is still handsome and it still goes, but it is a handsome mediocrity.
The film's triumph is Mitchum's definitive Marlowe, which captures perfectly the character's down-at-heel integrity and erratic emotional involvement with his cases.
Despite an impressive production and some firstrate performances, this third version fails to generate much suspense or excitement.
As movie makeovers go, this is a worthy effort, and thanks to Mitchum's presence, electric entertainment.

An affectionate adaptation of Raymond Chandler's novel that beautifully evokes the seamy side of 1940s Los Angeles via superb production design and the same period atmosphere cinematographer Alonzo previously evoked for Chinatown.

Watching this movie has approximately the same effect as being locked overnight in a secondhand clothing store in Pasadena. There is an awful lot of dust and, after a while, the dummies look as if they are moving.
Like the noir bible says, the only time Marlowe gets actual rest is when he's knocked out by some unseen party, always waking up surrounded by a corpse or two.
What you have here is a very solid film that zings as well as zigs and zags to keep you guessing.

Spencer Tracy's comic talent carries the more dated aspects of this sweet domestic tale.
An endless array of laughs and goosebump fodder
Middle-brow comedy that makes you wonder about Minnelli's reputation.
A honey of a picture of American family life.
Tracy is at his comic best in the title role -- the father torn by jealousy, devotion, pride and irritation as the problems mount in the run-up to his daughter's wedding.
First rate Hollywood comedy, with good support from its stars and Elizabeth Taylor at her loveliest.
Thoroughly enchanting comedy about the trials and tribulations a middle-aged family man faces when the daughter he dotes on decides to get married.
Nightmarish comedy, about the hunt for a wealthy husband and an expensive wedding.
On the critical side: Minnelli could have timed many of the scenes so that laughs would not have stepped on dialog tag lines.
Spencer Tracy gives a wonderful, Oscar-nominated performance in the titular role of this popular Minnelli- MGM comedy, which reflected the zeitgeist of post-WII America.
One of the best comedies MGM made in the 1950s.
Under Vincente Minelli's crisp direction, the fun rarely lets up.
This ostensibly lighthearted film about Spencer Tracy's Kafkaesque attempts to bring off his daughter's wedding is one of the bleakest films of a bleak decade.
Old-fashioned, star-studded, father-daughter comedy.

What makes the movie, and particularly Spencer Tracy's performance (arguably his finest), so exceptional is the manner in which it gently brings up the unavoidable heartbreak in this most enduring and celebrated of traditions.
Spencer Tracy underplays the comedy to good effect, and Joan Bennett and Elizabeth Taylor are beautiful and efficient.
What it needs - and never finds - is a few extraordinarily eccentric personas and some slapstick to even out the customariness of matrimonial stresses and wedding-day chaos.
It's a terrific and underrated action/adventure movie; especially compared to some of today's Summertime blockbuster "thrillers."
Absorbing study of men under pressure never flags
Don't watch this before your next flight.
A smart character study disguised as a thriller, and well worth viewing.
Relentless, gripping lost in desert vehicle.
This is a different kind of action movie, but it's all the better for it.
Gets exciting mileage out of examining male codes of honor and behavior.
A criminally underrated adventure classic.
Plays against convention by raising scary questions about leadership.
Directed by Aldrich, this disaster picture about a plane crash boasts a terrific ensemble cast, headed by Jimmy Stewart and inluding Peter Finch and Ian Bannen in Oscar nominated turn.
It's not hard to see the appeal of Robert Aldrich's The Flight of the Phoenix, a riveting adventure film featuring an all-star cast headed by Jimmy Stewart and Richard Attenborough.
It doesn't matter if the whole thing is improbable, because Aldrich keeps things moving, keeps up our interest in who will survive, and how.
a sunny windswept antidote to endless helpings of frantic Japanimation

Just about worth seeing, but probably not as good as you'd imagine.

Griffith's 'Intolerance' was way ahead of its time in terms of its camera angles, sophisticated storytelling, and elaborate set construction. And the restoration and HD treatment makes it shine.
D.W. Griffith's masterpiece, likely the most influential film ever made, has been given new life with a gold-standard digital cleanup.

Intolerance is undoubtedly cinematic paradigm, but more than this, it's a window through which we can peer 100 years into the past.
If Intolerance is sometimes quaint, it reminds one of what cinema might do at its most ideal. Griffith's hopes for the movies are still stirring

Brando is plainly miscast...

Brando makes a total mess of his English accent, the romantic interlude in Tahiti goes on endlessly, and the visuals (perhaps the main point of interest in the movie) too often resort to travelogue vistas and picture postcard lighting.

My Man Godfrey (1936) is one of the 1930s' delightful, classic screwball comedies. Directed by Gregory La Cava for Universal, the definitive social comedy
...clearly defines the screwball comedy...Powell and Lombard at their best and funniest. Yet...with a serious touch, juxtaposing the worlds of the haves and have-nots.
uses the screwball genre in unexpected ways, infusing social critique and a political message
A treasure.
A Great Depression film so blackly off its rocker it seems in many ways to be of our time more than its own.
Scintillating screwball comedy. One of the best.
Hugely popular in its day, this is witty romantic comedy with barbed social commentary.
There may be a sober moment or two in the picture; there may be a few lines of the script that do not pack a laugh. Somehow we cannot remember them.
A silvery romp.
The ultimate Depression-era satire of the idle rich and tribute to the noble poor. This popular theme was never more devastatingly realized than in this opening sequence

One of the most enchanting and poignant screwball comedies of all time, La Cava's zany film reflects the zeitgeist of the Depression and is supremely acted by William Powell, Carol Lombard and the rest of the ensemble.
The film has lost some of its allure over the years, but it's still streets and streets ahead of the addled whimsy favoured by latter-day Hollywood.
Its whimsical winning nature still comes through.
Director Gregory La Cava was a master of the sustained comedy.
William Powell and Carole Lombard are pleasantly teamed in this splendidly produced comedy.
A brilliantly executed screwball, full of both madcap humour and bitter satire.
[A] screwball masterpiece.
God, but this film is beautiful.
Gregory La Cava's improvisational style received its highest critical acclaim for this 1936 film, a marginally Marxist exercise in class confusion during the Depression.
My Man Godfrey emerges with that evasive quality that is not skillful playing, writing or direction, but something that mysteriously adds itself to these things, and makes a tip-top picture.
There's a charm to both Powell and Lombard, making the film transcend generations. It's a cute movie that has fun with levels of wealth in society and sibling rivalry.
Hasn't lost an ounce of its thematic resonance even after all these decades.
Gregory La Cava's warm and giddy carousel, a raucous burlesque with a beautiful still center, a lighter and tarter savior fable than Capra's concurrent transmutations of the Gospels
This scintillating comedy was the first film to be Oscar-nominated in all four acting categories.

George Romero's remarkably assured debut, made on a shoestring, about a group of people barricaded inside a farmhouse while an army of flesh-eating zombies roams the countryside, deflates all genre clichs.
Over its short, furious course, the picture violates so many strong taboos -- cannibalism, incest, necrophilia -- that it leaves audiences giddy and hysterical.
I felt real terror in that neighborhood theater last Saturday afternoon. I saw kids who had no resources they could draw upon to protect themselves from the dread and fear they felt.
Seldom have so many pundit parses and public praises owed so much to so little as in the case of the career-launching 'Night of the Living Dead.'

Oft-copied zombie classic is still intense and gory.

"Night of the Living Dead" became a seminal film without being a particularly good one. It nudged horror movies away from creepy-but-family-friendly into adult films featuring gruesome violence and nihilistic overtones.
The original and the best.

It's a virulent portrait of an America in flux and decay, from the flag billowing near the graveyard at the start to its disturbing depiction of a lynch-mob mentality. But Night also transcends its period through sheer intensity.
It's pitch perfect in writing, mood, and scares, and still holds up to scrutiny, no matter how harsh.
Subjects us to the kind of unrelenting nightmare we only wish we could wake up from.
If [Romero's] original vision of the undead looks dulled by today's standards, his embedded political commentary on racism feels just as sharp.
Director George A Romero redefined the meaning of horror for fear-sated audiences in the 1960s with this seminal classic.
Carve[s] open the guts of American culture, using violence and even the horror genre itself as a tool rather than an end.
The immediate, quasi-documentary feel, a result of budgetary constraints, actually served the film's horror, jolting audiences because it all seemed just a little too real.
All in all, Night of the Living Dead is obviously just as marvellous as it's always been.
A landmark of American cinema. Intentional or not, the film's sociopolitical content remains as potent as ever.

Night of the Living Dead (1968) is the first genuinely modern horror movie, shot more like a documentary of the apocalypse than the Gothic horrors that defined the sixties, and it bled right into the fabric of the culture.
Combined with Romero's political commentary is a cinematic aesthetic that arguably outstrips its sequels in both craft and effectiveness.

What's truly remarkable is how, after half a century and an uncountable number of zombie films, novels, comics, TV shows, and video games, you can watch the original Night of the Living Dead and it still feels fresh and terrifying.
It's tame of course by today's standards, but that, combined with he cynical racial component, was viewed as an all-out attack on "civilized" American society in general.
A slightly tacky horror picture which makes quite an impact; partly, I suspect, by ingeniously playing off its own limitations.

Carol Reed has made his film with deliberation and care, and has achieved splendid teamwork from every member of the cast. Occasionally too intent on pointing his moral and adorning his tale, he has missed little in its telling.

If there are to be gangster pictures, let them be like The Public Enemy, hard-boiled and vindictive almost to the point of burlesque.

Everyone should see Quo Vadis. Once.
the main reason to watch three hours of Quo Vadis remains Peter Ustinov's striking contribution to Nero lore

Pretty good, almost despite all the excess.
Super MGM spectacular, Roman style, headlining Robert Taylor.

By today's standards, Mervyn LeRoy's film is a kitschy spectacle, but in 1951, it was immensely popular and MGM spent its biggest budget to date for a star-driven production that shot for a whole year at Rome's Cinnecitta Studios.
It's heavy-handed, to be sure, but it's fun to watch, thanks to its pageantry and color.
It was made, we suspect, for those who like grandeur and noise -- and no punctuation. It will probably be a vast success.
It does last virtually three hours, and along the way does have stretches of tedium, but LeRoy invests most of it with pace, true spectacle, and not a little imagination.
Enough large-scale spectacle scenes to outweigh the inevitable religiose sludge that creeps in between them.
The epic Quo Vadis offers a spectacular cast to match its overwhelming production.

Quo Vadis is a super-spectacle in all its meaning.

sometimes claustrophic but powerful study of serious generational and racial issues
[An] intelligent screen adaptation of Lorraine Hansberry's groundbreaking play.
Ground-breaking in that this was the first drama by a black woman ever to be produced on Broadway, and the play was suspended in order for the original cast to be transported to Hollywood.
The performances are uniformly excellent.
It does have enough gritty insights and (for the time) strikingly accurate production details to keep the level of interest up.
Fine adaptation of stage play giving Poitier one of his first hits.

Classic based on the Pulitzer prize-winning play.
hits on an intertwined set of realities involving family conflict and deeply embedded social racism that still affects us today

A groundbreaking work that manages to be both specific to the African-American experience and universal in its themes of hope, change, and upward mobility.

Often pushing against Production Code limits, it is a fine execution of the novel

Edmund Goulding's version deserves crdit for trying to adapt Maugham's difficult existential movel, but Tyrone Power is miscast and the film is too melodramatic and verbose, failing to illustrate the novel's essence.

voyeuristic mystery is a masterpiece of meticulous detail.

Rear Window is the epitome of Hollywood class.

[This] 1954 thriller, often cited as one of the greatest films ever made, could be seen as some kind of ode to voyeurism.

One of the finest ever committed to celluloid!

In an impressive oeuvre, Rear Window is arguably the most exquisitely handcrafted feature, because Hitchcock mastered the spatial as well as behavioral coordinates of his chosen universe inch by inch.

This much-loved Hitchcock picture, based on the Cornell Woolrich story "It Had to Be Murder," is a superb example of suspense filmmaking, especially when one considers the technical limitations of its single set.
The clearest example of a Hitchcock movie that functions on dual levels: It's both mousetrap and abyss.
Witty, suspenseful, sad, funny and wise.
Rear Window lovingly invests in suspense all through the film, banking it in our memory, so that when the final payoff arrives, the whole film has been the thriller equivalent of foreplay.
What results is, in essence, one of the greatest films ever made.
Its appeal, which goes beyond that of other, equally masterly Hitchcock works, remains undiminished.
A cinematic treasure!
Hitchcock made more than a half-dozen films that lesser directors would gladly claim as a masterpiece. None surpasses the suspense, romance, wit and wisdom of Rear Window.

One of the most elegant entertainments ever made in Hollywood, and also one of the boldest and most personal of the Hitchcock films -- a work that's almost perverse in its giddy celebration of the thrill of voyeurism.

What a great movie.
Never to be surpassed, never to be repeated.

hitchcock perfection

a taut and (verbally) jaunty thriller

If someone who has never seen a Hitchcock film asked me to recommend the one they should see first, I would pick Rear Window.

A riveting masterpiece.
Right off the assembly line.

Walter Hill's direction's real cool, and the photography is beautiful. The film is also pretty funny. The leads are great.
''Red Heat'' is a topically entertaining variation on the sort of action-adventure nonsense that plays best on television.
This thing was a dud in the 80s. That's saying something.

Don't assume that Arnold is pure straight man here, though. He still gets his share of laughs, mostly based on the differences between east and west, and Belushi gets his shot at character and action.

Magical.

One of the most beautiful and heartbreaking films I have ever seen.

The team of Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger direct and write one of the great ballet melodramas of all time.
The film is voluptuous in its beauty and passionate in its storytelling. You don't watch it, you bathe in it.

A masterpiece from first frame to last, this is easily the most emotionally touching and artistically brilliant ballet melodrama ever made (don't even mention The Turning Point), whose stature grows as time goes by.

A look beneath its lushly romantic surface reveals a dark, complex sensibility, and that surface, rendered in the somber tones of British Technicolor, reflects a fantastically rich cinematic inventiveness.
The film obeys its own rules, but they work wonderfully.

Wrapped up with gorgeous sparkly colour, off-the-beaten-track classical music selections, and a sinister edge that perfectly catches the ambiguity of traditional as opposed to Disney fairy tales, this remains a luminous masterpiece.
The three principal dancers, Moira Shearer, Leonide Massine and Robert Helpmann, are beyond criticism.
One of the most beautiful films ever made.

What a cast, and what superbly florid but controlled direction. Unequalled Technicolor photography from Jack Cardiff. too.

Incorporating echoes of the Hans Christian Andersen fairytale that gives the film its name, Powell and Pressburger include visionary flashes of surrealism and magic realism.
A lingering, calf-eyed look at backstage ballet's little world of overworked egos and underdone glands.

On the whole, it is a fine motion picture, missing greatness through too many defects. However, the Ballet of the Red Shoes, is one of the finest sequences ever shown on any screen, anywhere.

review_content: The beauty of this film is that it was made before the hype that's surrounded both the holiday season and kids entertainment since the late 1970s.
Maybe the ultimate Christmas TV special.
One of the most beautiful, heartfelt holiday programs ever aired on broadcast television.
A paean to nonconformity that would be startling today, it must have been downright shocking in pre-hippie 1964, when it debuted.
A holiday must-watch (if your kids aren't scared silly by the Abominable Snowman, as I was).
All these years later, as a reminder that every oddball fits in somewhere, it still shines. You could even say it glows.
Still retains its charm and all-ages appeal decades after its original broadcasts.

Parents will no doubt have memories of this delightful film, which first aired in 1964, from their own childhoods. And you can't watch it without appreciating the simplicity of a pre-computer-animation world.
Rudolph would be nothing without its colorful cast of supporting characters-none of which Marks apparently felt worthy of inclusion in his original song.
Most days, I'm of the belief that Rudolph is the best Rankin-Bass Christmas special. It's iconic. It's a family tradition. It's about dentistry, at least in part.
This classic tale is still beloved today, as its feel-good story about the most famous reindeer of all wins every kid (and, fine, adult) over.

The characters in this Christmas special really make it... Rudolph and Hermey are wonderful examples of lovable misfits. And the wonderful thing about this special is that neither of these characters changes to fit their surroundings.
The best character in the special, and perhaps in all of Western literature: Yukon Cornelius, the greatest prospector in the world (Wahoooooo!).

Rudolph set the template for dozens of specials to come, from the theme of acceptance to celebrity narrators and original songs, but few ever matched the captivating high of the godfather of Christmas specials.
In some sense one might think of it as the mother recipe of the American Christmas special.

Sabotage is possibly Hitchcock's most viscerally effective pre-Hollywood film. And yet it is not remembered half as warmly as some of his other films from that period.
The individual genius of Hitchcock is very clearly shown in the distinctive and original direction.

Abundant charm and humour

Skip the Harrison Ford remake and go straight to this original classic.

A frothy delight.

it's odd that Wilder's script lacks a sharpness to balance all the love that's in the air
